item.title: Is Notion better than Moodle?
item.description: Gurri and Diebert present contrasting perspectives on what the network revolution means for government, and the contrast may be in large part a function of what they chose to focus on. By focusing on street protests and civil unrest caused by mobilized and radicalized, but leaderless factions unleashed by internet communications, Gurri sees the net as a threat to centralized rule, in both democratic and authoritarian states. He believes itâ€™s only a matter of time before even the largest strong-man regimes like Russia and China succumb to the instability and ultimately the toppling of government that unfolded in places like Egypt and Tunisia, or to the installation of populist government from Hungary to Brazil to the US.

item.title: About
item.description: I’m a law professor and a lawyer in British Columbia. I enjoy keeping up with new developments in technology and spending time with my wife and two children. I teach criminal law and evidence in the law school at Thompson Rivers University, in Kamloops BC. I have published papers on a few tech topics: compelled decryption, password compulsion, and global content takedown orders – along with a fair bit about national security.
